About Me

About me

Feb 14, 2016

I’ve been working in bioinformatics since 1999 in various areas: protein families, structural bioinformatics, protein domains (function and evolution), structural genomics, ligand-protein interactions, chemoinformatics, microarrays, high-throughput sequencing, RNA-Seq, variant calling, cluster pipeline creation, and cancer bioinformatics. Following a brief stint as a summer student working on Pfam with Alex Bateman at the Sanger, I did my PhD in the research group of Cyrus Chothia at the MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology in Cambridge on the evolution of protein function via the combination of protein domains. I then worked as a postdoc in the group of Janet Thornton at the EBI as part of the Midwest Centre for Structural Genomics (MCSG). From there I refocused my efforts to high-throughput methods working in the Bioinformatics Support Unit (BSU) a core facility at Newcastle University with Simon Cockell. During this time I developed an interest in cancer genomics and most recently I have moved on to the Northern Institute for Cancer Research (NICR).

My publications can be found here.
